article.title: Simple Theory of Ionic Activity in Concentrated Electrolytes

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the comparison of experimental data with Debye-Hückel (DH) and DH + Born models in Figure 1?
choices: Both DH and DH+Born models accurately predict activity coefficients for all salt concentrations.
DH+Born model significantly improves the fitting of activity data for concentrated solutions compared to DH, especially for monovalent salts.
The largest discrepancies between the models and experimental data are observed for monovalent cations.
The addition of Born solvation energy has a negligible effect on the accuracy of activity coefficient predictions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the adjustable parameter ξ in the BSK+Born model represent?
choices: Effective ionic radius
Solution permittivity
Correlation length scaling factor
Ionic strength

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the electrolyte system used in Figure 2?
choices: NaCl in water
LiPF6 in a mixture of carbonates
CaCl2 in water
KNO3 in water

multiple_choice_question.text: What approach is used to fit the data in Figure 2 to the BSK+Born model, since permittivity data is not available?
choices: ξ is adjusted to fit the activity data directly.
The correlation length lc is assumed to be equal to the Bjerrum length.
ξ is set to 1 and the dielectric decrements are fitted using known solvent permittivities.
The Born solvation energy is neglected.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main limitation of the BSK+Born model highlighted in Figure 3?
choices: Inability to accurately predict activity coefficients at high temperatures
Neglect of short-range specific interactions, especially at high concentrations
Overestimation of the Born solvation energy for all electrolytes
Inability to handle multivalent ions

multiple_choice_question.text: What specific interaction is suggested to explain the deviation of the BSK+Born model for KNO3 at high concentrations?
choices: Strong hydrogen bonding within the nitrate hydration shell
Fluctuating hydrogen bonds in the nitrate hydration shell
Formation of Bjerrum pairs between potassium and nitrate ions
Steric hindrance due to the large size of nitrate ions

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical phenomena does Equation (14) incorporate to model ionic activity?
choices: Only mean-field ion-ion correlations
Mean-field ion-ion correlations and ion-solvent self-energy
Mean-field ion-ion correlations, ion-solvent self-energy, and many-body ion-ion correlations
Only many-body ion-ion correlations
